item.title: Codex：基于云的多任务并行软件工程助手
item.content:encoded:
Codex是一款云平台软件工程代理，支持开发者同时处理多种编码任务。



摘要： Codex是一个由codex-1驱动的云服务型软件工程工具，它能够在同一时间并行执行多项任务。借助Codex，开发人员可以部署多个代理来同时处理多种编程相关的工作，例如编写功能代码、解答关于代码库的问题、修复错误以及提出供审查的合并请求。这种多任务并行处理能力极大地提高了开发效率，使团队能够更高效地协作和管理项目。

item.title: Codex：基于云的代码生成助手
item.content:encoded:
Codex是一款由Codex-1驱动的云原生编码助手。



摘要： Codex是由Codex-1驱动的一款云原生编码助手，Codex-1是OpenAI o3的一个优化版本，专门用于软件工程。该模型通过强化学习在多种环境中的实际编码任务上进行训练，能够生成接近人类风格且符合PR偏好的代码，严格遵循指令，并通过迭代测试直至获得正确结果。Codex的开发旨在提高编码效率并提供高质量的代码解决方案。

item.title: HealthBench：面向医疗AI的现实场景评估基准
item.content:encoded:
HealthBench是一个由250多位医生参与构建的医疗AI评估基准。



摘要： HealthBench 是一个全新的评估基准，专门用于评估人工智能在医疗领域的模型表现。它通过模拟真实的医疗场景来进行测试，旨在提供一个统一的标准，以衡量医疗AI模型的性能和安全性。该基准的设计得到了超过250位专业医师的贡献和支持，体现了实际医疗环境中的复杂性和挑战性，从而帮助开发者改进算法并确保其在真实世界中的有效应用。

item.title: Sam Altman：我们正进入智能时代
item.content:encoded:
Sam Altman认为AI将帮助人类解决重大问题并开启新可能。



摘要： Sam Altman指出，人类社会正在迈入一个被称为‘智能时代’的新阶段，在这个时代里，人工智能将极大地提升人们的潜力，使许多当前看似无法克服的问题变得可解决。无论是科学、医学、教育还是国家安全等领域都将从中受益，迎来前所未有的可能性和繁荣景象。这一转变不仅意味着技术的进步，更象征着人类应对挑战能力的一次飞跃，开启了更加光明的发展前景。

item.title: ChatGPT恢复早期版本：移除过于奉承的GPT-4o更新
item.content:encoded:
ChatGPT恢复早期版本以平衡行为，移除过于奉承的更新。



摘要： 上周，OpenAI在ChatGPT中引入了GPT-4o更新，但因其表现得过于奉承或过分同意用户的观点而受到批评，被形容为谄媚。鉴于此，OpenAI决定撤回这一更新，让用户重新使用之前版本，该版本的行为更为均衡且符合预期。此次调整旨在改善用户体验，避免因过于讨好而导致的不适感，同时确保模型保持客观和中立的态度。

item.title: GPT-4.1 API发布：全新模型家族带来多领域性能提升
item.content:encoded:
GPT-4.1 API发布，新模型家族在编程、指令执行及长上下文理解方面有显著改进。



摘要： GPT-4.1的API现已面向全球开发者推出，这一新模型家族带来了全方位的性能提升，尤其在代码生成能力、对指令的响应能力以及处理长文本的能力上取得了重大突破。此外，此次更新还推出了首个纳米级模型，进一步丰富了GPT系列的应用场景和灵活性。这些改进使得GPT-4.1在自然语言处理和机器学习领域具有更强的竞争力，为开发者提供了更强大的工具支持。随着API的全球上线，预计将在多个行业引发技术革新和应用扩展。

item.content:encoded:
OpenAI宣布将其盈利实体转型为公共利益公司。



摘要： 近期，OpenAI董事会发布了一项重要公告，宣布将现有的盈利实体转变为公共利益公司（Public Benefit Corporation）。这一转变旨在加强其使命驱动型组织架构，并在非营利组织的监管下实现更大的社会影响力。通过这种转型，OpenAI希望能够在追求商业利益的同时，更好地与公众利益保持长期一致，进一步推动技术发展服务于全人类的福祉。此举标志着OpenAI在治理结构上的重大调整，也体现了其对社会责任的高度重视。

But what’s more is that every three seconds someone gets hired on Indeed.

In addition to the wide range of use cases for developers and grit:lab students, 70% of Paf employees actively use ChatGPT Enterprise, spanning business teams like finance, HR, marketing, and customer support.

API Partnership with Stack Overflow

item.title: Reimagining secure infrastructure for advanced AI
item.content:encoded:
Securing advanced AI systems will require an evolution in infrastructure security. We’re calling for research and investment in six security measures that we believe will play key roles in protecting advanced AI.
Protecting, exploring, and applying advanced artificial intelligence (AI) is our strategic imperative. OpenAI’s mission is to deliver positive impact of advanced AI to everything from healthcare to science to education – and yes, even to cybersecurity. That work begins with building secure, trustworthy AI systems and protecting the underlying technologies from those who seek to subvert our work to cause harm.

item.title: OpenAI and Elon Musk
item.content:encoded: We are dedicated to the OpenAI mission and have pursued it every step of the way.

item.title: Video generation models as world simulators
item.content:encoded: We explore large-scale training of generative models on video data. Specifically, we train text-conditional diffusion models jointly on videos and images of variable durations, resolutions and aspect ratios. We leverage a transformer architecture that operates on spacetime patches of video and image latent codes. Our largest model, Sora, is capable of generating a minute of high fidelity video. Our results suggest that scaling video generation models is a promising path towards building general purpose simulators of the physical world.

item.title: Disrupting malicious uses of AI by state-affiliated threat actors
item.content:encoded: We terminated accounts associated with state-affiliated threat actors. Our findings show our models offer only limited, incremental capabilities for malicious cybersecurity tasks.

item.title: Memory and new controls for ChatGPT
item.content:encoded: We’re testing the ability for ChatGPT to remember things you discuss to make future chats more helpful. You’re in control of ChatGPT’s memory.

item.title: Building an early warning system for LLM-aided biological threat creation
item.content:encoded: We’re developing a blueprint for evaluating the risk that a large language model (LLM) could aid someone in creating a biological threat. In an evaluation involving both biology experts and students, we found that GPT-4 provides at most a mild uplift in biological threat creation accuracy. While this uplift is not large enough to be conclusive, our finding is a starting point for continued research and community deliberation.

item.title: New embedding models and API updates
item.content:encoded: We are launching a new generation of embedding models, new GPT-4 Turbo and moderation models, new API usage management tools, and soon, lower pricing on GPT-3.5 Turbo.

item.content:encoded: We funded 10 teams from around the world to design ideas and tools to collectively govern AI. We summarize the innovations, outline our learnings, and call for researchers and engineers to join us as we continue this work.

item.title: Improving mathematical reasoning with process supervision
item.content:encoded: We've trained a model to achieve a new state-of-the-art in mathematical problem solving by rewarding each correct step of reasoning (“process supervision”) instead of simply rewarding the correct final answer (“outcome supervision”). In addition to boosting performance relative to outcome supervision, process supervision also has an important alignment benefit: it directly trains the model to produce a chain-of-thought that is endorsed by humans.

item.title: Democratic inputs to AI
item.content:encoded: Our nonprofit organization, OpenAI, Inc., is launching a program to award ten $100,000 grants to fund experiments in setting up a democratic process for deciding what rules AI systems should follow, within the bounds defined by the law.

item.content:encoded: We use GPT-4 to automatically write explanations for the behavior of neurons in large language models and to score those explanations. We release a dataset of these (imperfect) explanations and scores for every neuron in GPT-2.

item.title: GPT-4
item.content:encoded: We’ve created GPT-4, the latest milestone in OpenAI’s effort in scaling up deep learning. GPT-4 is a large multimodal model (accepting image and text inputs, emitting text outputs) that, while less capable than humans in many real-world scenarios, exhibits human-level performance on various professional and academic benchmarks.

item.content:encoded: Our mission is to ensure that artificial general intelligence—AI systems that are generally smarter than humans—benefits all of humanity.

item.title: Forecasting potential misuses of language models for disinformation campaigns and how to reduce risk
item.content:encoded: OpenAI researchers collaborated with Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology and the Stanford Internet Observatory to investigate how large language models might be misused for disinformation purposes. The collaboration included an October 2021 workshop bringing together 30 disinformation researchers, machine learning experts, and policy analysts, and culminated in a co-authored report building on more than a year of research. This report outlines the threats that language models pose to the information environment if used to augment disinformation campaigns and introduces a framework for analyzing potential mitigations. Read the full report here.

item.title: Reducing bias and improving safety in DALL·E 2
item.content:encoded: Today, we are implementing a new technique so that DALL·E generates images of people that more accurately reflect the diversity of the world’s population.

item.title: DALL·E 2: Extending creativity
item.content:encoded: As part of our DALL·E 2 research preview, more than 3,000 artists from more than 118 countries have incorporated DALL·E into their creative workflows. The artists in our early access group have helped us discover new uses for DALL·E and have served as key voices as we’ve made decisions about DALL·E’s features.

item.title: DALL·E 2 pre-training mitigations
item.content:encoded: In order to share the magic of DALL·E 2 with a broad audience, we needed to reduce the risks associated with powerful image generation models. To this end, we put various guardrails in place to prevent generated images from violating our content policy.

item.title: Learning to play Minecraft with Video PreTraining
item.content:encoded: We trained a neural network to play Minecraft by Video PreTraining (VPT) on a massive unlabeled video dataset of human Minecraft play, while using only a small amount of labeled contractor data. With fine-tuning, our model can learn to craft diamond tools, a task that usually takes proficient humans over 20 minutes (24,000 actions). Our model uses the native human interface of keypresses and mouse movements, making it quite general, and represents a step towards general computer-using agents.

item.title: Evolution through large models
item.content:encoded: Evolution through large models

item.title: AI-written critiques help humans notice flaws
item.content:encoded: We trained “critique-writing” models to describe flaws in summaries. Human evaluators find flaws in summaries much more often when shown our model’s critiques. Larger models are better at self-critiquing, with scale improving critique-writing more than summary-writing. This shows promise for using AI systems to assist human supervision of AI systems on difficult tasks.

item.title: Techniques for training large neural networks
item.content:encoded: Large neural networks are at the core of many recent advances in AI, but training them is a difficult engineering and research challenge which requires orchestrating a cluster of GPUs to perform a single synchronized calculation.

item.title: Best practices for deploying language models
item.content:encoded: Cohere, OpenAI, and AI21 Labs have developed a preliminary set of best practices applicable to any organization developing or deploying large language models.

item.title: Measuring Goodhart’s law
item.content:encoded: Goodhart’s law famously says: “When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.” Although originally from economics, it’s something we have to grapple with at OpenAI when figuring out how to optimize objectives that are difficult or costly to measure.

item.title: New GPT-3 capabilities: Edit & insert
item.content:encoded: We’ve released new versions of GPT-3 and Codex which can edit or insert content into existing text, rather than just completing existing text.

item.content:encoded: We describe our latest thinking in the hope of helping other AI developers address safety and misuse of deployed models.

item.title: Solving (some) formal math olympiad problems
item.content:encoded: We built a neural theorem prover for Lean that learned to solve a variety of challenging high-school olympiad problems, including problems from the AMC12 and AIME competitions, as well as two problems adapted from the IMO.

item.title: Aligning language models to follow instructions
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained language models that are much better at following user intentions than GPT-3 while also making them more truthful and less toxic, using techniques developed through our alignment research. These InstructGPT models, which are trained with humans in the loop, are now deployed as the default language models on our API.

item.title: Introducing text and code embeddings
item.content:encoded: We are introducing embeddings, a new endpoint in the OpenAI API that makes it easy to perform natural language and code tasks like semantic search, clustering, topic modeling, and classification.

item.content:encoded: We’ve fine-tuned GPT-3 to more accurately answer open-ended questions using a text-based web browser.

item.title: Solving math word problems
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained a system that solves grade school math problems with nearly twice the accuracy of a fine-tuned GPT-3 model. It solves about 90% as many problems as real kids: a small sample of 9-12 year olds scored 60% on a test from our dataset, while our system scored 55% on those same problems.

item.title: OpenAI Codex
item.content:encoded: We’ve created an improved version of OpenAI Codex, our AI system that translates natural language to code, and we are releasing it through our API in private beta starting today.

item.title: Introducing Triton: Open-source GPU programming for neural networks
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing Triton 1.0, an open-source Python-like programming language which enables researchers with no CUDA experience to write highly efficient GPU code—most of the time on par with what an expert would be able to produce.

item.title: Improving language model behavior by training on a curated dataset
item.content:encoded: Our latest research finds we can improve language model behavior with respect to specific behavioral values by fine-tuning on a small, curated dataset.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2021: Final projects
item.content:encoded: We’re proud to announce that the 2021 class of OpenAI Scholars has completed our six-month mentorship program and have produced an open-source research project with stipends and support from OpenAI.

item.title: Will Hurd joins OpenAI’s board of directors
item.content:encoded: OpenAI is committed to developing general-purpose artificial intelligence that benefits all humanity, and we believe that achieving our goal requires expertise in public policy as well as technology. So, we’re delighted to announce that Congressman Will Hurd has joined our board of directors.

item.title: GPT-3 powers the next generation of apps
item.content:encoded: Over 300 applications are delivering GPT-3–powered search, conversation, text completion, and other advanced AI features through our API.

item.title: Multimodal neurons in artificial neural networks
item.content:encoded: We’ve discovered neurons in CLIP that respond to the same concept whether presented literally, symbolically, or conceptually. This may explain CLIP’s accuracy in classifying surprising visual renditions of concepts, and is also an important step toward understanding the associations and biases that CLIP and similar models learn.

item.title: Understanding the capabilities, limitations, and societal impact of large language models
item.content:encoded: Understanding the capabilities, limitations, and societal impact of large language models

item.title: Scaling Kubernetes to 7,500 nodes
item.content:encoded: We’ve scaled Kubernetes clusters to 7,500 nodes, producing a scalable infrastructure for large models like GPT-3, CLIP, and DALL·E, but also for rapid small-scale iterative research such as Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models.

item.title: DALL·E: Creating images from text
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained a neural network called DALL·E that creates images from text captions for a wide range of concepts expressible in natural language.

item.title: CLIP: Connecting text and images
item.content:encoded: We’re introducing a neural network called CLIP which efficiently learns visual concepts from natural language supervision. CLIP can be applied to any visual classification benchmark by simply providing the names of the visual categories to be recognized, similar to the “zero-shot” capabilities of GPT-2 and GPT-3.

item.title: Organizational update from OpenAI
item.content:encoded: It’s been a year of dramatic change and growth at OpenAI.

item.title: Learning to summarize with human feedback
item.content:encoded: We’ve applied reinforcement learning from human feedback to train language models that are better at summarization.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2020: Final projects
item.content:encoded: Our third class of OpenAI Scholars presented their final projects at virtual Demo Day, showcasing their research results from over the past five months.

item.title: Procgen and MineRL Competitions
item.content:encoded: We’re excited to announce that OpenAI is co-organizing two NeurIPS 2020 competitions with AIcrowd, Carnegie Mellon University, and DeepMind, using Procgen Benchmark and MineRL.

item.title: Image GPT
item.content:encoded: We find that, just as a large transformer model trained on language can generate coherent text, the same exact model trained on pixel sequences can generate coherent image completions and samples. By establishing a correlation between sample quality and image classification accuracy, we show that our best generative model also contains features competitive with top convolutional nets in the unsupervised setting.

item.title: OpenAI API
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing an API for accessing new AI models developed by OpenAI.

item.title: Language models are few-shot learners
item.content:encoded: Language models are few-shot learners

item.title: AI and efficiency
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing an analysis showing that since 2012 the amount of compute needed to train a neural net to the same performance on ImageNet classification has been decreasing by a factor of 2 every 16 months. Compared to 2012, it now takes 44 times less compute to train a neural network to the level of AlexNet (by contrast, Moore’s Law would yield an 11x cost improvement over this period). Our results suggest that for AI tasks with high levels of recent investment, algorithmic progress has yielded more gains than classical hardware efficiency.

item.title: Jukebox
item.content:encoded: We’re introducing Jukebox, a neural net that generates music, including rudimentary singing, as raw audio in a variety of genres and artist styles. We’re releasing the model weights and code, along with a tool to explore the generated samples.

item.title: Improving verifiability in AI development
item.content:encoded: We’ve contributed to a multi-stakeholder report by 58 co-authors at 30 organizations, including the Centre for the Future of Intelligence, Mila, Schwartz Reisman Institute for Technology and Society, Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, and Center for Security and Emerging Technologies. This report describes 10 mechanisms to improve the verifiability of claims made about AI systems. Developers can use these tools to provide evidence that AI systems are safe, secure, fair, or privacy-preserving. Users, policymakers, and civil society can use these tools to evaluate AI development processes.

item.title: OpenAI Microscope
item.content:encoded: We’re introducing OpenAI Microscope, a collection of visualizations of every significant layer and neuron of eight vision “model organisms” which are often studied in interpretability. Microscope makes it easier to analyze the features that form inside these neural networks, and we hope it will help the research community as we move towards understanding these complicated systems.

item.title: OpenAI standardizes on PyTorch
item.content:encoded: We are standardizing OpenAI’s deep learning framework on PyTorch.

item.title: Scaling laws for neural language models
item.content:encoded: Scaling laws for neural language models

item.title: Dota 2 with large scale deep reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded: Dota 2 with large scale deep reinforcement learning

item.title: Deep double descent
item.content:encoded: We show that the double descent phenomenon occurs in CNNs, ResNets, and transformers: performance first improves, then gets worse, and then improves again with increasing model size, data size, or training time. This effect is often avoided through careful regularization. While this behavior appears to be fairly universal, we don’t yet fully understand why it happens, and view further study of this phenomenon as an important research direction.

item.title: Procgen Benchmark
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing Procgen Benchmark, 16 simple-to-use procedurally-generated environments which provide a direct measure of how quickly a reinforcement learning agent learns generalizable skills.

item.title: Benchmarking safe exploration in deep reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded: Benchmarking safe exploration in deep reinforcement learning

item.title: Safety Gym
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing Safety Gym, a suite of environments and tools for measuring progress towards reinforcement learning agents that respect safety constraints while training.

item.title: GPT-2: 1.5B release
item.content:encoded: As the final model release of GPT-2’s staged release, we’re releasing the largest version (1.5B parameters) of GPT-2 along with code and model weights to facilitate detection of outputs of GPT-2 models. While there have been larger language models released since August, we’ve continued with our original staged release plan in order to provide the community with a test case of a full staged release process. We hope that this test case will be useful to developers of future powerful models, and we’re actively continuing the conversation with the AI community on responsible publication.

item.title: Solving Rubik’s Cube with a robot hand
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained a pair of neural networks to solve the Rubik’s Cube with a human-like robot hand. The neural networks are trained entirely in simulation, using the same reinforcement learning code as OpenAI Five paired with a new technique called Automatic Domain Randomization (ADR). The system can handle situations it never saw during training, such as being prodded by a stuffed giraffe. This shows that reinforcement learning isn’t just a tool for virtual tasks, but can solve physical-world problems requiring unprecedented dexterity.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2020: Applications open
item.content:encoded: We are now accepting applications for our third class of OpenAI Scholars.

item.title: Fine-tuning GPT-2 from human preferences
item.content:encoded: We’ve fine-tuned the 774M parameter GPT-2 language model using human feedback for various tasks, successfully matching the preferences of the external human labelers, though those preferences did not always match our own. Specifically, for summarization tasks the labelers preferred sentences copied wholesale from the input (we’d only asked them to ensure accuracy), so our models learned to copy. Summarization required 60k human labels; simpler tasks which continue text in various styles required only 5k. Our motivation is to move safety techniques closer to the general task of “machines talking to humans,” which we believe is key to extracting information about human values.

item.title: Emergent tool use from multi-agent interaction
item.content:encoded: We’ve observed agents discovering progressively more complex tool use while playing a simple game of hide-and-seek. Through training in our new simulated hide-and-seek environment, agents build a series of six distinct strategies and counterstrategies, some of which we did not know our environment supported. The self-supervised emergent complexity in this simple environment further suggests that multi-agent co-adaptation may one day produce extremely complex and intelligent behavior.

item.title: Testing robustness against unforeseen adversaries
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed a method to assess whether a neural network classifier can reliably defend against adversarial attacks not seen during training. Our method yields a new metric, UAR (Unforeseen Attack Robustness), which evaluates the robustness of a single model against an unanticipated attack, and highlights the need to measure performance across a more diverse range of unforeseen attacks.

item.title: GPT-2: 6-month follow-up
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing the 774 million parameter GPT-2 language model after the release of our small 124M model in February, staged release of our medium 355M model in May, and subsequent research with partners and the AI community into the model’s potential for misuse and societal benefit. We’re also releasing an open-source legal agreement to make it easier for organizations to initiate model-sharing partnerships with each other, and are publishing a technical report about our experience in coordinating with the wider AI research community on publication norms.

item.title: Learning Day
item.content:encoded: At OpenAI, each Thursday is Learning Day: a day where employees have the option to self-study technical skills that will make them better at their job but which aren’t being learned from daily work.

item.title: Microsoft invests in and partners with OpenAI to support us building beneficial AGI
item.content:encoded: Microsoft is investing $1 billion in OpenAI to support us building artificial general intelligence (AGI) with widely distributed economic benefits. We’re partnering to develop a hardware and software platform within Microsoft Azure which will scale to AGI. We’ll jointly develop new Azure AI supercomputing technologies, and Microsoft will become our exclusive cloud provider—so we’ll be working hard together to further extend Microsoft Azure’s capabilities in large-scale AI systems.

item.title: Why responsible AI development needs cooperation on safety
item.content:encoded: We’ve written a policy research paper identifying four strategies that can be used today to improve the likelihood of long-term industry cooperation on safety norms in AI: communicating risks and benefits, technical collaboration, increased transparency, and incentivizing standards. Our analysis shows that industry cooperation on safety will be instrumental in ensuring that AI systems are safe and beneficial, but competitive pressures could lead to a collective action problem, potentially causing AI companies to under-invest in safety. We hope these strategies will encourage greater cooperation on the safe development of AI and lead to better global outcomes of AI.

item.title: OpenAI Robotics Symposium 2019
item.content:encoded: We hosted the first OpenAI Robotics Symposium on April 27, 2019.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2019: Final projects
item.content:encoded: Our second class of OpenAI Scholars has concluded, with all eight scholars producing an exciting final project showcased at Scholars Demo Day at OpenAI.

item.title: OpenAI Fellows Fall 2018: Final projects
item.content:encoded: Our second class of OpenAI Fellows has wrapped up, with each Fellow going from a machine learning beginner to core OpenAI contributor in the course of a 6-month apprenticeship. We are currently reviewing applications on a rolling basis for our next round of OpenAI Fellows Summer 2019.

item.title: Transfer of adversarial robustness between perturbation types
item.content:encoded: Transfer of adversarial robustness between perturbation types

item.title: MuseNet
item.content:encoded: We’ve created MuseNet, a deep neural network that can generate 4-minute musical compositions with 10 different instruments, and can combine styles from country to Mozart to the Beatles. MuseNet was not explicitly programmed with our understanding of music, but instead discovered patterns of harmony, rhythm, and style by learning to predict the next token in hundreds of thousands of MIDI files. MuseNet uses the same general-purpose unsupervised technology as GPT-2, a large-scale transformer model trained to predict the next token in a sequence, whether audio or text.

item.title: Generative modeling with sparse transformers
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed the Sparse Transformer, a deep neural network which sets new records at predicting what comes next in a sequence—whether text, images, or sound. It uses an algorithmic improvement of the attention mechanism to extract patterns from sequences 30x longer than possible previously.

item.title: OpenAI Five defeats Dota 2 world champions
item.content:encoded: OpenAI Five is the first AI to beat the world champions in an esports game, having won two back-to-back games versus the world champion Dota 2 team, OG, at Finals this weekend. Both OpenAI Five and DeepMind’s AlphaStar had previously beaten good pros privately but lost their live pro matches, making this also the first time an AI has beaten esports pros on livestream.

item.title: OpenAI Five Finals
item.content:encoded: We’ll be holding our final live event for OpenAI Five at 11:30am PT on April 13.

item.title: Implicit generation and generalization methods for energy-based models
item.content:encoded: We’ve made progress towards stable and scalable training of energy-based models (EBMs) resulting in better sample quality and generalization ability than existing models. Generation in EBMs spends more compute to continually refine its answers and doing so can generate samples competitive with GANs at low temperatures, while also having mode coverage guarantees of likelihood-based models. We hope these findings stimulate further research into this promising class of models.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2019: Meet our Scholars
item.content:encoded: Our class of eight scholars (out of 550 applicants) brings together collective expertise in literature, philosophy, cell biology, statistics, economics, quantum physics, and business innovation.

item.title: OpenAI LP
item.content:encoded: We’ve created OpenAI LP, a new “capped-profit” company that allows us to rapidly increase our investments in compute and talent while including checks and balances to actualize our mission.

item.title: Introducing Activation Atlases
item.content:encoded: We’ve created activation atlases (in collaboration with Google researchers), a new technique for visualizing what interactions between neurons can represent. As AI systems are deployed in increasingly sensitive contexts, having a better understanding of their internal decision-making processes will let us identify weaknesses and investigate failures.

item.title: Neural MMO: A massively multiagent game environment
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing a Neural MMO, a massively multiagent game environment for reinforcement learning agents. Our platform supports a large, variable number of agents within a persistent and open-ended task. The inclusion of many agents and species leads to better exploration, divergent niche formation, and greater overall competence.

item.title: Spinning Up in Deep RL: Workshop review
item.content:encoded: On February 2, we held our first Spinning Up Workshop as part of our new education initiative at OpenAI.

item.title: AI safety needs social scientists
item.content:encoded: We’ve written a paper arguing that long-term AI safety research needs social scientists to ensure AI alignment algorithms succeed when actual humans are involved. Properly aligning advanced AI systems with human values requires resolving many uncertainties related to the psychology of human rationality, emotion, and biases. The aim of this paper is to spark further collaboration between machine learning and social science researchers, and we plan to hire social scientists to work on this full time at OpenAI.

item.title: Better language models and their implications
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained a large-scale unsupervised language model which generates coherent paragraphs of text, achieves state-of-the-art performance on many language modeling benchmarks, and performs rudimentary reading comprehension, machine translation, question answering, and summarization—all without task-specific training.

item.title: Computational limitations in robust classification and win-win results
item.content:encoded: Computational limitations in robust classification and win-win results

item.title: OpenAI Fellows Summer 2018: Final projects
item.content:encoded: Our first cohort of OpenAI Fellows has concluded, with each Fellow going from a machine learning beginner to core OpenAI contributor in the course of a 6-month apprenticeship.

item.title: How AI training scales
item.content:encoded: We’ve discovered that the gradient noise scale, a simple statistical metric, predicts the parallelizability of neural network training on a wide range of tasks. Since complex tasks tend to have noisier gradients, increasingly large batch sizes are likely to become useful in the future, removing one potential limit to further growth of AI systems. More broadly, these results show that neural network training need not be considered a mysterious art, but can be rigorized and systematized.

item.title: Quantifying generalization in reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing CoinRun, a training environment which provides a metric for an agent’s ability to transfer its experience to novel situations and has already helped clarify a longstanding puzzle in reinforcement learning. CoinRun strikes a desirable balance in complexity: the environment is simpler than traditional platformer games like Sonic the Hedgehog but still poses a worthy generalization challenge for state of the art algorithms.

item.title: Spinning Up in Deep RL
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing Spinning Up in Deep RL, an educational resource designed to let anyone learn to become a skilled practitioner in deep reinforcement learning. Spinning Up consists of crystal-clear examples of RL code, educational exercises, documentation, and tutorials.

item.title: Learning concepts with energy functions
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed an energy-based model that can quickly learn to identify and generate instances of concepts, such as near, above, between, closest, and furthest, expressed as sets of 2d points. Our model learns these concepts after only five demonstrations. We also show cross-domain transfer: we use concepts learned in a 2d particle environment to solve tasks on a 3-dimensional physics-based robot.

item.title: Plan online, learn offline: Efficient learning and exploration via model-based control
item.content:encoded: Plan online, learn offline: Efficient learning and exploration via model-based control

item.title: Reinforcement learning with prediction-based rewards
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed Random Network Distillation (RND), a prediction-based method for encouraging reinforcement learning agents to explore their environments through curiosity, which for the first time exceeds average human performance on Montezuma’s Revenge.

item.title: Learning complex goals with iterated amplification
item.content:encoded: We’re proposing an AI safety technique called iterated amplification that lets us specify complicated behaviors and goals that are beyond human scale, by demonstrating how to decompose a task into simpler sub-tasks, rather than by providing labeled data or a reward function. Although this idea is in its very early stages and we have only completed experiments on simple toy algorithmic domains, we’ve decided to present it in its preliminary state because we think it could prove to be a scalable approach to AI safety.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2019: Applications open
item.content:encoded: We are now accepting applications for our second cohort of OpenAI Scholars, a program where we provide 6–10 stipends and mentorship to individuals from underrepresented groups to study deep learning full-time for 3 months and open-source a project.

item.title: OpenAI Fellows Winter 2019 & Interns Summer 2019
item.content:encoded: We are now accepting applications for OpenAI Fellows and Interns for 2019.

item.title: FFJORD: Free-form continuous dynamics for scalable reversible generative models
item.content:encoded: FFJORD: Free-form continuous dynamics for scalable reversible generative models

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2018: Final projects
item.content:encoded: Our first cohort of OpenAI Scholars has now completed the program.

item.title: The International 2018: Results
item.content:encoded: OpenAI Five lost two games against top Dota 2 players at The International in Vancouver this week, maintaining a good chance of winning for the first 20–35 minutes of both games.

item.title: Large-scale study of curiosity-driven learning
item.content:encoded: Large-scale study of curiosity-driven learning

item.title: OpenAI Five Benchmark: Results
item.content:encoded: Yesterday, OpenAI Five won a best-of-three against a team of 99.95th percentile Dota players: Blitz, Cap, Fogged, Merlini, and MoonMeander—four of whom have played Dota professionally—in front of a live audience and 100,000 concurrent livestream viewers.

item.title: Learning dexterity
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained a human-like robot hand to manipulate physical objects with unprecedented dexterity.

item.title: Variational option discovery algorithms
item.content:encoded: Variational option discovery algorithms

item.title: OpenAI Scholars 2018: Meet our Scholars
item.content:encoded: Our first class of OpenAI Scholars is underway, and you can now follow along as this group of experienced software developers becomes machine learning practitioners.

item.title: OpenAI Five Benchmark
item.content:encoded: The OpenAI Five Benchmark match is now over!

item.title: Glow: Better reversible generative models
item.content:encoded: We introduce Glow, a reversible generative model which uses invertible 1x1 convolutions. It extends previous work on reversible generative models and simplifies the architecture. Our model can generate realistic high resolution images, supports efficient sampling, and discovers features that can be used to manipulate attributes of data. We’re releasing code for the model and an online visualization tool so people can explore and build on these results.

item.title: Learning Montezuma’s Revenge from a single demonstration
item.content:encoded: We’ve trained an agent to achieve a high score of 74,500 on Montezuma’s Revenge from a single human demonstration, better than any previously published result. Our algorithm is simple: the agent plays a sequence of games starting from carefully chosen states from the demonstration, and learns from them by optimizing the game score using PPO, the same reinforcement learning algorithm that underpins OpenAI Five.

item.title: OpenAI Five
item.content:encoded: Our team of five neural networks, OpenAI Five, has started to defeat amateur human teams at Dota 2.

item.title: Retro Contest: Results
item.content:encoded: The first run of our Retro Contest—exploring the development of algorithms that can generalize from previous experience—is now complete.

item.title: Learning policy representations in multiagent systems
item.content:encoded: Learning policy representations in multiagent systems

item.title: Improving language understanding with unsupervised learning
item.content:encoded: We’ve obtained state-of-the-art results on a suite of diverse language tasks with a scalable, task-agnostic system, which we’re also releasing. Our approach is a combination of two existing ideas: transformers and unsupervised pre-training. These results provide a convincing example that pairing supervised learning methods with unsupervised pre-training works very well; this is an idea that many have explored in the past, and we hope our result motivates further research into applying this idea on larger and more diverse datasets.

item.title: GamePad: A learning environment for theorem proving
item.content:encoded: GamePad: A learning environment for theorem proving

item.title: OpenAI Fellows Fall 2018
item.content:encoded: We’re now accepting applications for the next cohort of OpenAI Fellows, a program which offers a compensated 6-month apprenticeship in AI research at OpenAI.

item.title: Gym Retro
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing the full version of Gym Retro, a platform for reinforcement learning research on games. This brings our publicly-released game count from around 70 Atari games and 30 Sega games to over 1,000 games across a variety of backing emulators. We’re also releasing the tool we use to add new games to the platform.

item.title: AI and compute
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing an analysis showing that since 2012, the amount of compute used in the largest AI training runs has been increasing exponentially with a 3.4-month doubling time (by comparison, Moore’s Law had a 2-year doubling period)[^footnote-correction]. Since 2012, this metric has grown by more than 300,000x (a 2-year doubling period would yield only a 7x increase). Improvements in compute have been a key component of AI progress, so as long as this trend continues, it’s worth preparing for the implications of systems far outside today’s capabilities.

item.title: AI safety via debate
item.content:encoded: We’re proposing an AI safety technique which trains agents to debate topics with one another, using a human to judge who wins.

item.title: Evolved Policy Gradients
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing an experimental metalearning approach called Evolved Policy Gradients, a method that evolves the loss function of learning agents, which can enable fast training on novel tasks. Agents trained with EPG can succeed at basic tasks at test time that were outside their training regime, like learning to navigate to an object on a different side of the room from where it was placed during training.

item.title: Gotta Learn Fast: A new benchmark for generalization in RL
item.content:encoded: Gotta Learn Fast: A new benchmark for generalization in RL

item.title: Retro Contest
item.content:encoded: We’re launching a transfer learning contest that measures a reinforcement learning algorithm’s ability to generalize from previous experience.

item.title: Variance reduction for policy gradient with action-dependent factorized baselines
item.content:encoded: Variance reduction for policy gradient with action-dependent factorized baselines

item.title: Improving GANs using optimal transport
item.content:encoded: Improving GANs using optimal transport

item.title: Report from the OpenAI hackathon
item.content:encoded: On March 3rd, we hosted our first hackathon with 100 members of the artificial intelligence community.

item.title: On first-order meta-learning algorithms
item.content:encoded: On first-order meta-learning algorithms

item.title: Reptile: A scalable meta-learning algorithm
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed a simple meta-learning algorithm called Reptile which works by repeatedly sampling a task, performing stochastic gradient descent on it, and updating the initial parameters towards the final parameters learned on that task. Reptile is the application of the Shortest Descent algorithm to the meta-learning setting, and is mathematically similar to first-order MAML (which is a version of the well-known MAML algorithm) that only needs black-box access to an optimizer such as SGD or Adam, with similar computational efficiency and performance.

item.title: OpenAI Scholars
item.content:encoded: We’re providing 6–10 stipends and mentorship to individuals from underrepresented groups to study deep learning full-time for 3 months and open-source a project.

item.title: Some considerations on learning to explore via meta-reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded: Some considerations on learning to explore via meta-reinforcement learning

item.title: Multi-Goal Reinforcement Learning: Challenging robotics environments and request for research
item.content:encoded: Multi-Goal Reinforcement Learning: Challenging robotics environments and request for research

item.title: Ingredients for robotics research
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing eight simulated robotics environments and a Baselines implementation of Hindsight Experience Replay, all developed for our research over the past year. We’ve used these environments to train models which work on physical robots. We’re also releasing a set of requests for robotics research.

item.title: OpenAI hackathon
item.content:encoded: Come to OpenAI’s office in San Francisco’s Mission District for talks and a hackathon on Saturday, March 3rd.

item.title: OpenAI supporters
item.content:encoded: We’re excited to welcome new donors to OpenAI.

item.title: Preparing for malicious uses of AI
item.content:encoded: We’ve co-authored a paper that forecasts how malicious actors could misuse AI technology, and potential ways we can prevent and mitigate these threats. This paper is the outcome of almost a year of sustained work with our colleagues at the Future of Humanity Institute, the Centre for the Study of Existential Risk, the Center for a New American Security, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, and others.

item.title: Interpretable machine learning through teaching
item.content:encoded: We’ve designed a method that encourages AIs to teach each other with examples that also make sense to humans. Our approach automatically selects the most informative examples to teach a concept—for instance, the best images to describe the concept of dogs—and experimentally we found our approach to be effective at teaching both AIs

item.title: Discovering types for entity disambiguation
item.content:encoded: We’ve built a system for automatically figuring out which object is meant by a word by having a neural network decide if the word belongs to each of about 100 automatically-discovered “types” (non-exclusive categories).

item.title: Requests for Research 2.0
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing a new batch of seven unsolved problems which have come up in the course of our research at OpenAI.

item.title: Scaling Kubernetes to 2,500 nodes
item.content:encoded: Scaling Kubernetes to 2,500 nodes

item.title: Block-sparse GPU kernels
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing highly-optimized GPU kernels for an underexplored class of neural network architectures: networks with block-sparse weights. Depending on the chosen sparsity, these kernels can run orders of magnitude faster than cuBLAS or cuSPARSE. We’ve used them to attain state-of-the-art results in text sentiment analysis and generative modeling of text and images.

item.title: Learning sparse neural networks through L₀ regularization
item.content:encoded: Learning sparse neural networks through L₀ regularization

item.title: Interpretable and pedagogical examples
item.content:encoded: Interpretable and pedagogical examples

item.title: Learning a hierarchy
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm that learns high-level actions useful for solving a range of tasks, allowing fast solving of tasks requiring thousands of timesteps. Our algorithm, when applied to a set of navigation problems, discovers a set of high-level actions for walking and crawling in different directions, which enables the agent to master new navigation tasks quickly.

item.title: Generalizing from simulation
item.content:encoded: Our latest robotics techniques allow robot controllers, trained entirely in simulation and deployed on physical robots, to react to unplanned changes in the environment as they solve simple tasks. That is, we’ve used these techniques to build closed-loop systems rather than open-loop ones as before.

item.title: Asymmetric actor critic for image-based robot learning
item.content:encoded: Asymmetric actor critic for image-based robot learning

item.title: Sim-to-real transfer of robotic control with dynamics randomization
item.content:encoded: Sim-to-real transfer of robotic control with dynamics randomization

item.title: Domain randomization and generative models for robotic grasping
item.content:encoded: Domain randomization and generative models for robotic grasping

item.title: Competitive self-play
item.content:encoded: We’ve found that self-play allows simulated AIs to discover physical skills like tackling, ducking, faking, kicking, catching, and diving for the ball, without explicitly designing an environment with these skills in mind. Self-play ensures that the environment is always the right difficulty for an AI to improve. Taken alongside our Dota 2 self-play results, we have increasing confidence that self-play will be a core part of powerful AI systems in the future.

item.title: Meta-learning for wrestling
item.content:encoded: We show that for the task of simulated robot wrestling, a meta-learning agent can learn to quickly defeat a stronger non-meta-learning agent, and also show that the meta-learning agent can adapt to physical malfunction.

item.title: Nonlinear computation in deep linear networks
item.content:encoded: Nonlinear computation in deep linear networks

item.title: Learning to model other minds
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing an algorithm which accounts for the fact that other agents are learning too, and discovers self-interested yet collaborative strategies like tit-for-tat in the iterated prisoner’s dilemma. This algorithm, Learning with Opponent-Learning Awareness (LOLA), is a small step towards agents that model other minds.

item.title: Learning with opponent-learning awareness
item.content:encoded: Learning with opponent-learning awareness

item.title: OpenAI Baselines: ACKTR & A2C
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing two new OpenAI Baselines implementations: ACKTR and A2C. A2C is a synchronous, deterministic variant of Asynchronous Advantage Actor Critic (A3C) which we’ve found gives equal performance. ACKTR is a more sample-efficient reinforcement learning algorithm than TRPO and A2C, and requires only slightly more computation than A2C per update.

item.title: More on Dota 2
item.content:encoded: Our Dota 2 result shows that self-play can catapult the performance of machine learning systems from far below human level to superhuman, given sufficient compute. In the span of a month, our system went from barely matching a high-ranked player to beating the top pros and has continued to improve since then. Supervised deep learning systems can only be as good as their training datasets, but in self-play systems, the available data improves automatically as the agent gets better.

item.title: Dota 2
item.content:encoded: We’ve created a bot which beats the world’s top professionals at 1v1 matches of Dota 2 under standard tournament rules. The bot learned the game from scratch by self-play, and does not use imitation learning or tree search. This is a step towards building AI systems which accomplish well-defined goals in messy, complicated situations involving real humans.

item.title: Gathering human feedback
item.content:encoded: RL-Teacher is an open-source implementation of our interface to train AIs via occasional human feedback rather than hand-crafted reward functions. The underlying technique was developed as a step towards safe AI systems, but also applies to reinforcement learning problems with rewards that are hard to specify.

item.title: Better exploration with parameter noise
item.content:encoded: We’ve found that adding adaptive noise to the parameters of reinforcement learning algorithms frequently boosts performance. This exploration method is simple to implement and very rarely decreases performance, so it’s worth trying on any problem.

item.title: Proximal Policy Optimization
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing a new class of reinforcement learning algorithms, Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), which perform comparably or better than state-of-the-art approaches while being much simpler to implement and tune. PPO has become the default reinforcement learning algorithm at OpenAI because of its ease of use and good performance.

item.title: Robust adversarial inputs
item.content:encoded: We’ve created images that reliably fool neural network classifiers when viewed from varied scales and perspectives. This challenges a claim from last week that self-driving cars would be hard to trick maliciously since they capture images from multiple scales, angles, perspectives, and the like.

item.title: Hindsight Experience Replay
item.content:encoded: Hindsight Experience Replay

item.title: Teacher–student curriculum learning
item.content:encoded: Teacher–student curriculum learning

item.title: Faster physics in Python
item.content:encoded: We’re open-sourcing a high-performance Python library for robotic simulation using the MuJoCo engine, developed over our past year of robotics research.

item.title: Learning from human preferences
item.content:encoded: One step towards building safe AI systems is to remove the need for humans to write goal functions, since using a simple proxy for a complex goal, or getting the complex goal a bit wrong, can lead to undesirable and even dangerous behavior. In collaboration with DeepMind’s safety team, we’ve developed an algorithm which can infer what humans want by being told which of two proposed behaviors is better.

item.title: Learning to cooperate, compete, and communicate
item.content:encoded: Multiagent environments where agents compete for resources are stepping stones on the path to AGI. Multiagent environments have two useful properties: first, there is a natural curriculum—the difficulty of the environment is determined by the skill of your competitors (and if you’re competing against clones of yourself, the environment exactly matches your skill level). Second, a multiagent environment has no stable equilibrium: no matter how smart an agent is, there’s always pressure to get smarter. These environments have a very different feel from traditional environments, and it’ll take a lot more research before we become good at them.

item.title: UCB exploration via Q-ensembles
item.content:encoded: UCB exploration via Q-ensembles

item.title: OpenAI Baselines: DQN
item.content:encoded: We’re open-sourcing OpenAI Baselines, our internal effort to reproduce reinforcement learning algorithms with performance on par with published results. We’ll release the algorithms over upcoming months; today’s release includes DQN and three of its variants.

item.title: Robots that learn
item.content:encoded: We’ve created a robotics system, trained entirely in simulation and deployed on a physical robot, which can learn a new task after seeing it done once.

item.title: Roboschool
item.content:encoded: We are releasing Roboschool: open-source software for robot simulation, integrated with OpenAI Gym.

item.title: Equivalence between policy gradients and soft Q-learning
item.content:encoded: Equivalence between policy gradients and soft Q-learning

item.title: Unsupervised sentiment neuron
item.content:encoded: We’ve developed an unsupervised system which learns an excellent representation of sentiment, despite being trained only to predict the next character in the text of Amazon reviews.

item.title: Spam detection in the physical world
item.content:encoded: We’ve created the world’s first Spam-detecting AI trained entirely in simulation and deployed on a physical robot.

item.title: Evolution strategies as a scalable alternative to reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded: We’ve discovered that evolution strategies (ES), an optimization technique that’s been known for decades, rivals the performance of standard reinforcement learning (RL) techniques on modern RL benchmarks (e.g. Atari/MuJoCo), while overcoming many of RL’s inconveniences.

item.title: Distill
item.content:encoded: We’re excited to support today’s launch of Distill, a new kind of journal aimed at excellent communication of machine learning results (novel or existing).

item.title: Learning to communicate
item.content:encoded: In this post we’ll outline new OpenAI research in which agents develop their own language.

item.title: Attacking machine learning with adversarial examples
item.content:encoded: Adversarial examples are inputs to machine learning models that an attacker has intentionally designed to cause the model to make a mistake; they’re like optical illusions for machines. In this post we’ll show how adversarial examples work across different mediums, and will discuss why securing systems against them can be difficult.

item.title: Team update
item.content:encoded: The OpenAI team is now 45 people. Together, we’re pushing the frontier of AI capabilities—whether by validating novel ideas, creating new software systems, or deploying machine learning on robots.

item.title: Faulty reward functions in the wild
item.content:encoded: Reinforcement learning algorithms can break in surprising, counterintuitive ways. In this post we’ll explore one failure mode, which is where you misspecify your reward function.

item.title: Universe
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing Universe, a software platform for measuring and training an AI’s general intelligence across the world’s supply of games, websites and other applications.

item.title: Infrastructure for deep learning
item.content:encoded: Deep learning is an empirical science, and the quality of a group’s infrastructure is a multiplier on progress. Fortunately, today’s open-source ecosystem makes it possible for anyone to build great deep learning infrastructure.

item.title: Machine Learning Unconference
item.content:encoded: The latest information about the Unconference is now available at the Unconference wiki, which will be periodically updated with more information for attendees.

item.title: Team update
item.content:encoded: We’ve hired more great people to help us achieve our goals. Welcome, everyone!

item.title: Special projects
item.content:encoded: Impactful scientific work requires working on the right problems—problems which are not just interesting, but whose solutions matter.

item.title: Concrete AI safety problems
item.content:encoded: We (along with researchers from Berkeley and Stanford) are co-authors on today’s paper led by Google Brain researchers, Concrete Problems in AI Safety. The paper explores many research problems around ensuring that modern machine learning systems operate as intended.

item.title: OpenAI technical goals
item.content:encoded: OpenAI’s mission is to build safe AI, and ensure AI’s benefits are as widely and evenly distributed as possible.

item.title: Generative models
item.content:encoded: This post describes four projects that share a common theme of enhancing or using generative models, a branch of unsupervised learning techniques in machine learning. In addition to describing our work, this post will tell you a bit more about generative models: what they are, why they are important, and where they might be going.

item.title: OpenAI Gym Beta
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing the public beta of OpenAI Gym, a toolkit for developing and comparing reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. It consists of a growing suite of environments (from simulated robots to Atari games), and a site for comparing and reproducing results.

item.title: Introducing OpenAI
item.content:encoded: OpenAI is a non-profit artificial intelligence research company. Our goal is to advance digital intelligence in the way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return. Since our research is free from financial obligations, we can better focus on a positive human impact.
